faqs.question: How much does it cost to paint a room in the UK?
faqs.answer: A standard bedroom costs £250-500 to paint including walls, ceiling, and basic woodwork. Larger rooms cost £400-700. The price depends on room size, preparation required, paint quality, and number of coats. Always get itemized quotes to understand what's included.

faqs.question: Should I supply the paint or let the decorator buy it?
faqs.answer: Most decorators prefer to supply materials as they get trade discounts and know which products work best. However, you can supply your own paint if you want specific brands or colors. Discuss this upfront - some decorators may not warranty work done with customer-supplied materials.

faqs.question: How long does it take to paint a house?
faqs.answer: A 3-bedroom house interior typically takes 5-10 days depending on preparation required. Single rooms take 1-2 days including drying time between coats. Exterior painting takes 3-7 days depending on size and weather conditions. Always factor in drying time between coats.

faqs.question: What's the difference between trade and retail paint prices?
faqs.answer: Trade paint typically costs 20-30% less than retail prices but is only available to registered decorators. However, trade paint is often higher quality and covers better than budget retail options. Professional decorators' material costs are usually competitive with DIY retail prices.

faqs.question: Do I need to prime walls before painting?
faqs.answer: Primer is essential when changing colors dramatically (light to dark or vice versa), painting over stains, or painting new plaster. Most modern paints have good coverage, but primer ensures even color and better adhesion. Your decorator will advise based on your specific situation.

faqs.question: How often should I redecorate my home?
faqs.answer: Interior walls typically need repainting every 5-7 years in living areas, longer in bedrooms. Woodwork needs attention every 3-5 years. Exterior painting lasts 7-10 years with quality paint systems. High-traffic areas like hallways may need more frequent touch-ups.

title: Carpenter Costs UK 2026: Complete Price Guide for Carpentry Work
excerpt: How much do carpenters charge in 2026? Fitted kitchen costs, door hanging, skirting boards, built-in wardrobes, and staircase prices across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Carpentry work ranges from simple repairs to complex fitted furniture installation. In 2026, carpenters charge £25-50 per hour depending on specialization and location, with project-based pricing often more cost-effective for larger jobs. Here's everything you need to know about carpenter costs in the UK.
Average Carpenter Hourly and Day Rates

Carpenter hourly rates vary by skill level and location: General carpenters charge £25-40 per hour, qualified joiners command £30-45 per hour, while specialist cabinet makers earn £40-60 per hour. Regional variations are significant: London and South East rates reach £40-60 per hour, the Midlands and North average £25-40 per hour, while Scotland and Wales typically charge £30-45 per hour.

Daily rates range from £200-350 for standard carpentry work, with specialist work commanding £300-500 per day. Most carpenters prefer project-based pricing for larger jobs like kitchen fitting or staircase installation.
Common Carpentry Jobs and Typical Costs

Hang internal door: £80-150 including basic adjustments. Install skirting boards: £8-15 per linear metre including materials. Fit window sill: £60-120 depending on material and complexity. Build basic shelving: £50-150 per linear metre installed. Repair floorboards: £30-80 per square metre depending on extent. Install stair spindles: £15-30 each plus labour. Box in pipes: £100-250 depending on length and access.
Fitted Kitchen Installation Costs

Kitchen fitting is specialist work commanding higher rates: Basic kitchen installation: £1,500-3,000 (flat-pack units, standard appliances). Custom kitchen installation: £3,000-8,000+ (bespoke units, complex layouts). The cost depends on kitchen size, unit complexity, appliance integration, and any structural modifications needed. Most kitchen fitters charge £300-500 per day and jobs typically take 3-10 days.
Additional costs include plumbing connections (£200-500), electrical work (£300-800), and wall/ceiling preparation (£200-600).
Built-in Wardrobe and Storage Costs

Fitted wardrobes are priced per linear metre: Basic MDF wardrobes: £200-400 per metre including installation. Mid-range wardrobes with better internals: £400-700 per metre. High-end hardwood or custom wardrobes: £700-1,500+ per metre. A typical 3-metre bedroom wall costs £800-2,500 for fitted wardrobes depending on specification and internal fittings.
Staircase Installation and Repair Costs

Staircase work is highly specialized: Replace stair treads: £50-150 each depending on material. Install new spindles and handrail: £800-2,000 for typical stairs. Full staircase replacement: £2,000-6,000+ depending on design and materials. Loft staircase installation: £500-1,500 for basic stairs, £1,500-4,000 for feature stairs.
What Affects Carpentry Costs?

Several factors influence final pricing: Material choice (MDF vs hardwood significantly affects cost), project complexity (custom work costs more than standard sizes), access and working conditions (tight spaces and height increase difficulty), finish requirements (painted vs stained vs natural finishes), and any structural modifications needed (moving walls, strengthening floors).
Carpenter vs Joiner: What's the Difference?

Carpenters typically work on-site doing structural work, fitting kitchens, hanging doors, and general repairs. Joiners work in workshops creating bespoke furniture, windows, and fitted units before installing them. Joiners often charge more (£30-50+ per hour) due to their specialized skills and workshop overheads.
Materials: Supply vs Labor Only

Carpenters work both ways: Supply and fit: Carpenter supplies all materials, convenient but you pay markup on materials. Labor only: You supply materials, potentially cheaper but you take responsibility for sourcing and delivery. For large projects, getting multiple quotes for both approaches helps determine the most cost-effective option.
How to Keep Carpentry Costs Down

Choose standard sizes rather than custom dimensions where possible. Source your own materials if the carpenter agrees. Bundle multiple jobs into one visit to reduce setup time. Provide clear, unobstructed access to work areas. Consider MDF for painted finishes rather than hardwood. Get detailed quotes comparing different material options.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to hang a door in the UK?
faqs.answer: Door hanging costs £80-150 including basic adjustments and hardware fitting. The price includes trimming the door to size, mortising hinges, and ensuring proper operation. Heavy doors or complex adjustments may cost more. This doesn't include the door itself or any frame repairs.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a carpenter and joiner?
faqs.answer: Carpenters work mainly on-site doing structural work, fitting kitchens, and general carpentry. Joiners work in workshops creating bespoke items like windows, doors, and fitted furniture before installing them. Joiners typically charge more (£30-50+ per hour) due to specialized skills.

faqs.question: How much do fitted wardrobes cost?
faqs.answer: Fitted wardrobes cost £200-1,500+ per linear metre depending on materials and specification. A typical 3-metre bedroom wall costs £800-2,500. Basic MDF wardrobes are cheapest, while hardwood or high-specification units cost significantly more. Internal fittings and accessories add to the price.

faqs.question: Should I supply materials or let the carpenter provide them?
faqs.answer: Both approaches work. Carpenters supplying materials is convenient and they take responsibility for quality and quantity. Supplying your own materials can be cheaper but requires accurate measuring and timely delivery. Discuss both options and compare total costs including your time.

faqs.question: How long does kitchen installation take?
faqs.answer: Kitchen installation typically takes 3-10 days depending on complexity. Basic flat-pack kitchens take 3-5 days, while bespoke kitchens can take 7-14 days. This includes unit installation, worktop fitting, and basic adjustments. Additional trades (plumber, electrician) add time.

faqs.question: What qualifications should a carpenter have?
faqs.answer: Look for City & Guilds Level 2 or 3 in Carpentry and Joinery, NVQ Level 2 or 3, or equivalent qualifications. Many carpenters also have apprenticeship training. For specialist work like kitchen fitting, specific training and experience matter more than general qualifications.

title: Builder Costs UK 2026: Complete Price Guide for Building Work
excerpt: How much do builders charge in 2026? Extension costs, loft conversions, garage conversions, day rates, and groundwork prices across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Building work encompasses everything from small repairs to major extensions and conversions. In 2026, general builders charge £200-400 per day depending on experience and location, while specialist contractors command higher rates. Here's your complete guide to builder costs in the UK.
Average Builder Day and Hourly Rates

General builders typically charge £200-350 per day, with regional variations: London and South East command £300-500 per day, the Midlands and North average £200-300 per day, while Scotland and Wales range from £250-350 per day. Hourly rates vary from £25-45 for general building work, rising to £35-60 for specialist trades within building teams.
Experienced builders with established reputations and specialist skills (period property restoration, complex structural work) can charge £350-500+ per day.
Extension Costs and Pricing

Single-story rear extensions cost £1,200-2,000 per square metre including all trades and finishes. Two-story extensions cost £1,500-2,500 per square metre due to additional structural requirements. A typical 4x4m single-story extension costs £20,000-35,000 including planning, building control, and all construction work. Complex designs, structural glazing, or premium finishes can increase costs to £2,500-3,500 per square metre.
Loft Conversion Costs

Loft conversions vary significantly by complexity: Simple roof light conversion: £20,000-35,000 for basic bedroom. Dormer conversion: £35,000-60,000 for bedroom with en-suite. Full hip-to-gable conversion: £50,000-85,000 for complex layouts. Mansard conversions: £60,000-120,000+ for maximum space creation. Costs include structural work, insulation, electrics, plumbing, and basic finishes.
Garage Conversion Costs

Garage conversions are popular for additional living space: Basic conversion to habitable room: £8,000-15,000. Conversion with kitchen/bathroom: £15,000-25,000. High-specification conversion with bi-fold doors: £20,000-35,000. Costs depend on existing garage condition, services required, and finish quality. Planning permission may be needed for certain changes.
Groundwork and Foundation Costs

Groundwork is specialized and typically subcontracted: Strip foundations: £80-150 per linear metre depending on depth. Concrete slab: £40-80 per square metre including base preparation. Drainage connections: £500-1,500 per connection depending on distance. Excavation: £15-30 per cubic metre depending on access and soil type. Most groundwork requires Building Control approval adding £400-800 to project costs.
What Affects Building Costs?

Multiple factors influence final pricing: Project complexity and design (simple rectangular extensions cost less than complex shapes), site conditions and access (restricted access increases material delivery costs), existing building condition (structural issues add costs), planning and building control requirements (complex applications cost more), material specifications (budget vs premium finishes significantly affect costs), and subcontractor availability (high demand periods increase prices).
Planning Permission and Building Control Costs

Most building projects need approvals: Planning permission: £206-462 for householder applications. Building control: £400-1,200 depending on project size. Party wall agreements: £700-2,000 if required. Structural engineer reports: £500-1,500 for calculations. Architectural drawings: £1,000-5,000 depending on complexity. Factor these costs into your total budget.
Builder vs Main Contractor

Small builders often work directly with minimal markup on subcontractors. Main contractors provide project management but add 15-25% to subcontractor costs. For complex projects, main contractors offer single-point responsibility and coordination. For simpler work, direct builders can be more cost-effective.
How to Keep Building Costs Down

Get detailed written quotes from multiple builders comparing like-for-like specifications. Book work during quieter periods (autumn/winter) when some builders offer better rates. Use permitted development rights to avoid planning permission where possible. Choose standard materials and fittings over bespoke options. Provide clear site access and consider material storage. Allow sufficient time - rushed jobs cost more.

faqs.question: How much does a house extension cost per square metre in 2026?
faqs.answer: Single-story extensions cost £1,200-2,000 per square metre, while two-story extensions cost £1,500-2,500 per square metre. Costs include all trades, materials, and basic finishes. Premium specifications or complex designs can increase costs to £2,500-3,500 per square metre. Always get detailed quotes for accurate pricing.

faqs.question: Do I need planning permission for my extension?
faqs.answer: Many extensions fall under permitted development rights and don't need planning permission. However, larger extensions, those near boundaries, or in conservation areas often require planning permission. Check with your local planning authority or consult a planning consultant. Building control approval is nearly always required regardless of planning.

faqs.question: How long does a typical extension take to build?
faqs.answer: A single-story extension typically takes 8-12 weeks from start to finish. Two-story extensions take 12-16 weeks. Loft conversions take 6-12 weeks depending on complexity. Weather, planning delays, and material availability can extend timelines. Always build contingency time into your plans.

faqs.question: Should I use a main contractor or individual trades?
faqs.answer: Main contractors provide project management and single-point responsibility but add 15-25% markup. Using individual trades can be cheaper but requires you to coordinate timing and manage multiple relationships. Consider your available time and project management skills when deciding.

faqs.question: What's included in a builder's quote?
faqs.answer: Builder quotes vary widely in what's included. Always ask for itemized quotes detailing labor, materials, subcontractor costs, waste removal, and any extras. Check whether VAT, planning fees, building control, and utilities connections are included. Unclear quotes often lead to unexpected costs later.

faqs.question: How much should I budget for project overruns?
faqs.answer: Budget 10-20% contingency for unforeseen issues like structural problems, planning complications, or material price increases. Complex projects or older properties may need higher contingencies. Having a buffer prevents project delays when unexpected costs arise.

title: Landscaping Costs UK 2026: Complete Garden Design and Installation Price Guide
excerpt: How much does landscaping cost in 2026? Patio laying, turfing, garden design, fencing, and driveway prices across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Garden landscaping transforms outdoor spaces but costs vary enormously depending on design complexity, materials chosen, and site conditions. In 2026, expect to pay £200-300 per day for landscapers, with project costs ranging from £3,000 for basic garden refreshes to £50,000+ for complete luxury redesigns. Here's everything you need to know about landscaping costs.
Average Landscaper Day Rates and Pricing

Landscaper day rates vary by skill level and region: General landscapers charge £200-275 per day, specialist garden designers command £300-500 per day for design work, while skilled craftspeople (stone masons, water feature specialists) earn £250-400 per day. London and South East rates are typically 20-30% higher than national averages.
Many landscaping projects are priced per square metre or as fixed-price packages rather than daily rates, especially for patios, turfing, and driveways.
Patio Installation Costs

Patio costs depend heavily on material choice: Concrete slabs: £35-60 per square metre installed. Natural stone paving: £60-120 per square metre installed. Premium stone (sandstone, granite): £80-160+ per square metre installed. Block paving: £50-90 per square metre installed. A typical 20 square metre patio costs £1,000-3,200 depending on materials and preparation required.
Additional costs include excavation (£15-25 per cubic metre), sub-base preparation (£8-15 per square metre), and drainage if required (£200-600).
Lawn Installation and Turfing Costs

New lawn installation varies by method: Turf installation: £10-20 per square metre including ground preparation. Seed sowing: £5-12 per square metre including soil preparation. Artificial grass: £25-60 per square metre installed. For an average 100 square metre garden, budget £1,000-2,000 for natural turf or £2,500-6,000 for quality artificial grass.
Ground preparation is crucial and adds £8-15 per square metre for soil improvement, leveling, and fertilizer.
Garden Design Costs

Professional garden design services range widely: Basic design consultation: £200-500 for site visit and concept ideas. Detailed design plans: £800-2,500 for scaled drawings and planting plans. Full design service: £2,000-8,000+ including 3D visualizations and construction drawings. Many designers charge 10-15% of the total project value, with minimum fees of £1,000-2,000.
Fencing Installation Costs

Fencing costs per linear metre vary by type: Closeboard fencing: £40-65 per metre installed. Panel fencing: £30-50 per metre installed. Post and rail fencing: £25-40 per metre installed. Premium hardwood fencing: £60-120+ per metre installed. A typical 30-metre garden perimeter costs £900-1,950 for standard fencing, plus £50-150 per gate.
Concrete posts cost £10-20 more per panel but last longer than wooden posts in most soil conditions.
Driveway Installation Costs

Driveway costs depend on material and size: Gravel driveways: £25-45 per square metre. Tarmac driveways: £45-75 per square metre. Block paving driveways: £60-100 per square metre. Resin bound driveways: £70-120 per square metre. Natural stone driveways: £80-180+ per square metre. A typical double driveway (40 square metres) costs £2,000-7,200 depending on materials.
What Affects Landscaping Costs?

Several factors significantly impact pricing: Site access and conditions (narrow access increases material delivery costs), existing garden condition (clearing overgrown gardens adds time), drainage requirements (poor drainage needs expensive solutions), levels and slopes (retaining walls and steps add complexity), material choice (natural stone costs 2-3x more than concrete), and design complexity (curved edges, patterns, and features increase installation time).
Planting and Soft Landscaping Costs

Plants and soft landscaping add life to gardens: Shrub planting: £15-40 per plant including soil improvement. Tree planting: £50-300+ per tree depending on size. Flower borders: £25-80 per square metre for plants and preparation. Hedge planting: £12-35 per linear metre depending on height and species. Annual maintenance contracts cost £200-800+ per year depending on garden size.
How to Keep Landscaping Costs Down

Choose local materials to reduce delivery costs. Phase work over multiple years to spread costs. Do basic clearance and preparation work yourself. Choose permeable paving to avoid drainage systems. Plant smaller specimens - they establish better and cost less. Get multiple quotes and compare material specifications carefully.

faqs.question: How much does a complete garden makeover cost in the UK?
faqs.answer: Complete garden makeovers cost £10,000-50,000+ depending on size and specification. Basic refreshes (new lawn, simple patio, planting) start around £5,000-15,000. Luxury gardens with premium materials, water features, and complex designs can exceed £100,000. Always get detailed quotes for accurate pricing.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a landscaper and garden designer?
faqs.answer: Garden designers create plans and concepts but may not do physical work. Landscapers implement designs and do the construction work. Many landscapers also offer basic design services. For complex projects, hiring both a designer and landscaper often produces better results.

faqs.question: How much does artificial grass cost compared to natural turf?
faqs.answer: Artificial grass costs £25-60 per square metre installed versus £10-20 for natural turf. However, artificial grass has no ongoing maintenance costs while natural lawns need regular mowing, feeding, and care. Artificial grass pays for itself over 10-15 years in maintenance savings.

faqs.question: Do I need planning permission for landscaping work?
faqs.answer: Most landscaping doesn't need planning permission, but check for: raised patios over 30cm high, structures near boundaries, driveways affecting drainage, or work in conservation areas. Building regulations may apply to retaining walls over 1.2m high. Always check with your local authority if unsure.

faqs.question: When is the best time to do landscaping work?
faqs.answer: Spring (March-May) and early autumn (September-October) are ideal for planting. Hard landscaping can be done year-round except in extreme weather. Winter work may be cheaper as landscapers are less busy, but weather can cause delays. Plan major projects to avoid peak wedding/barbecue season.

faqs.question: How long does landscaping work take?
faqs.answer: Simple projects (lawn installation, basic patio) take 3-7 days. Complete garden makeovers take 2-8 weeks depending on complexity. Weather delays are common, especially for ground work. Phased projects spread over seasons allow plants to establish and spread costs.

title: Tiling Costs UK 2026: Complete Price Guide for Bathroom and Kitchen Tiling
excerpt: How much does tiling cost in 2026? Bathroom tiling, kitchen splashback, floor tiling per m², wall tiling, and material costs across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Tiling costs vary significantly depending on tile type, area size, surface preparation, and design complexity. In 2026, expect to pay £20-60 per square metre for professional tiling installation, with bathroom tiling typically costing more due to waterproofing requirements. Here's your complete guide to UK tiling costs.
Average Tiler Day Rates and Pricing Methods

Tilers typically charge per square metre rather than hourly rates: Standard wall tiling: £20-40 per square metre installed. Floor tiling: £25-50 per square metre installed. Bathroom tiling (including waterproofing): £30-60 per square metre installed. Complex patterns or small tiles: £40-80 per square metre due to increased labor time.
Some tilers charge daily rates of £200-350, particularly for larger areas or when significant preparation work is required.
Bathroom Tiling Costs

Bathroom tiling requires waterproofing and precision: Small bathroom (walls only): £800-1,500 for standard tiles. Medium bathroom (walls and floor): £1,200-2,500 including preparation. Large bathroom with shower enclosure: £2,000-4,000+ depending on tile choice. Wet room waterproofing adds £200-500 to labor costs but is essential for leak prevention.
Bathroom tiling typically costs 30-50% more than other areas due to waterproofing requirements, precision cutting around fittings, and the need for high-quality adhesives and grouts.
Kitchen Tiling and Splashback Costs

Kitchen tiling focuses on splashbacks and sometimes floors: Basic splashback (3-4 square metres): £200-600 including materials. Full wall tiling around kitchen: £600-1,500 depending on area. Kitchen floor tiling (15-20 square metres): £500-1,200 plus tile costs. Large format tiles are popular in kitchens and cost £25-45 per square metre to install.
Floor Tiling Costs by Room Type

Floor tiling costs depend on room type and preparation needed: Living room/hallway: £25-45 per square metre for ceramic/porcelain. Bathroom floor: £30-55 per square metre including waterproofing. Kitchen floor: £25-50 per square metre depending on tile size. Conservatory floor: £20-40 per square metre (usually easier access).
Floor preparation adds £5-15 per square metre for leveling compound, priming, or removing existing flooring.
Tile Material Costs

Tile prices vary enormously by type and quality: Basic ceramic tiles: £8-25 per square metre. Porcelain tiles: £15-50 per square metre. Natural stone tiles: £25-80+ per square metre. Designer or large format tiles: £30-150+ per square metre. Mosaic tiles: £20-100+ per square metre depending on material.
Always order 10-15% extra tiles for breakages, cuts, and future repairs. Adhesive, grout, and trims add £3-8 per square metre to material costs.
What Affects Tiling Costs?

Several factors influence final pricing: Surface preparation requirements (removing old tiles, leveling walls/floors), tile size and complexity (large tiles install faster, small mosaics take longer), pattern complexity (straight runs are fastest, diagonal or herringbone patterns take 30-50% longer), cutting requirements (bathrooms need many cuts around fittings), and waterproofing needs (wet areas require tanking systems).
Bathroom Waterproofing and Tanking

Proper waterproofing is essential in wet areas: Basic waterproofing (shower area): £200-400. Full bathroom tanking: £400-800 depending on area. Wet room waterproofing: £600-1,200 for complete installation. This prevents water damage and is required for warranties on bathroom installations. Never skip waterproofing to save money.
Removing Old Tiles and Preparation

Preparation often represents significant cost: Removing old wall tiles: £8-15 per square metre. Removing old floor tiles: £10-20 per square metre. Wall preparation and skimming: £8-18 per square metre. Floor leveling: £8-25 per square metre depending on extent. Always factor preparation into total project costs.
How to Keep Tiling Costs Down

Choose standard size tiles rather than large format or mosaics. Opt for straight laying patterns rather than diagonal or complex designs. Remove old tiles yourself if possible (but leave waterproofing to professionals). Buy tiles during sales but ensure you get enough for the entire project. Consider mid-range tiles rather than premium brands - the installation labor cost is the same.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to tile a bathroom in the UK?
faqs.answer: Bathroom tiling costs £800-4,000+ depending on size and tile choice. A standard bathroom costs £1,200-2,500 including walls and floor. This includes waterproofing, labor, adhesive, and grout. Luxury tiles or complex designs cost significantly more. Always get itemized quotes.

faqs.question: What's the difference between wall and floor tiling costs?
faqs.answer: Floor tiling typically costs £25-50 per square metre while wall tiling costs £20-40 per square metre. Floors require more preparation, leveling, and often use larger, more expensive tiles. Bathroom floors need waterproofing which adds to costs.

faqs.question: How long does tiling take?
faqs.answer: A standard bathroom takes 3-5 days including preparation and grouting. Kitchen splashbacks take 1-2 days. Large floor areas take 1-2 days per room plus drying time. Complex patterns or extensive preparation can double these times. Always allow for adhesive curing before use.

faqs.question: Should I remove old tiles myself?
faqs.answer: You can remove old tiles yourself to save £8-20 per square metre, but it's dusty, hard work. Leave wall preparation and waterproofing to professionals. In bathrooms, improper removal can damage waterproofing, leading to expensive repairs later. Consider the time and effort involved.

faqs.question: Do I need waterproofing for bathroom tiling?
faqs.answer: Yes, waterproofing is essential in wet areas like showers and around baths. It costs £200-800 extra but prevents water damage, mold, and structural problems. All reputable tilers include waterproofing in bathroom quotes. Skipping this step voids warranties and causes expensive problems.

faqs.question: What tiles are best for bathrooms?
faqs.answer: Porcelain tiles are ideal for bathrooms - they're water-resistant, durable, and available in many styles. Ceramic tiles are cheaper but more porous. Natural stone needs sealing and more maintenance. Choose tiles with low water absorption rates for wet areas.

title: Fencing Costs Per Metre 2026: Complete UK Price Guide
excerpt: How much does fencing cost per metre in 2026? Panel vs closeboard prices, post replacement, gate installation, and fence repair costs across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Garden fencing costs depend on fence type, height, ground conditions, and installation complexity. In 2026, expect to pay £30-80 per metre for standard fencing installation, with premium materials and complex sites costing significantly more. Here's everything you need to know about UK fencing costs.
Average Fencing Costs Per Metre by Type

Panel fencing (most popular): £30-50 per metre installed including posts. Closeboard fencing (premium option): £40-65 per metre installed. Picket fencing: £35-60 per metre depending on height and style. Post and rail fencing: £25-40 per metre for rural boundaries. Trellis fencing: £20-40 per metre for decorative applications. Security fencing (commercial): £45-120+ per metre depending on specification.
These prices include standard wooden posts, gravel boards, and basic installation. Concrete posts add £5-10 per metre but last longer in most soil conditions.
Panel vs Closeboard Fencing: Cost Comparison

Panel fencing uses pre-made panels between posts: Cheaper to install (£30-50 per metre). Faster installation (1-2 days for typical garden). Standard heights: 3ft, 4ft, 5ft, 6ft. Limited customization options. Easier to replace damaged sections.

Closeboard fencing is built on-site with individual boards: More expensive (£40-65 per metre). Slower installation (2-4 days for typical garden). Fully customizable height and spacing. More durable and attractive finish. Better wind resistance due to gaps between boards.
Fence Height and Cost Implications

Fence height significantly affects costs: 3ft fencing: £25-40 per metre (decorative boundaries). 4ft fencing: £30-45 per metre (low privacy). 5ft fencing: £35-55 per metre (standard privacy). 6ft fencing: £40-65 per metre (full privacy). 8ft+ fencing: £60-120+ per metre (security/commercial applications).
Heights over 2 metres may require planning permission, especially near highways or in conservation areas.
Post Replacement and Repair Costs

Individual post replacement costs: Wooden posts: £25-45 each including installation. Concrete posts: £35-60 each including installation. Steel posts: £45-80 each depending on type. Panel replacement: £40-80 each depending on size and quality. Gravel board replacement: £8-15 per metre.
Post repairs (re-concreting, bracing) cost £15-35 each and can extend fence life significantly.
Gate Installation Costs

Garden gates add significant cost to fencing projects: Standard wooden gate (3ft wide): £120-250 installed. Wide access gate (6ft double): £250-450 installed. Security gate with lock: £200-400 installed. Automated gates: £800-2,500+ depending on mechanism. Gate posts need extra concrete and bracing, adding £50-100 to installation costs.
What Affects Fencing Costs?

Several factors influence final pricing: Ground conditions (rock, clay, or waterlogged soil increases digging difficulty), access to site (narrow passages require hand digging and smaller equipment), existing fence removal (adds £5-15 per metre), slope and levels (stepped fencing on slopes costs more), boundary disputes (may require surveyor involvement), and material quality (pressure-treated timber lasts longer but costs more initially).
Fence Materials and Longevity

Material choice affects both cost and lifespan: Softwood fencing (most common): 10-15 year lifespan with maintenance. Hardwood fencing: 15-25 year lifespan, costs 30-50% more. Composite fencing: 25+ year lifespan, costs 100-200% more initially. Metal fencing: 20-50+ year lifespan depending on coating and maintenance.
Pressure-treated timber adds £5-10 per metre but significantly extends life in wet conditions.
Planning Permission and Neighbor Considerations

Most domestic fencing doesn't need planning permission but check for: Fencing over 2 metres high. Fencing over 1 metre near highways. Work in conservation areas or listed building curtilage. Always discuss boundary fencing with neighbors and establish ownership. Boundary disputes can delay projects and add legal costs.
Seasonal Pricing and Best Time to Install

Fencing can be installed year-round but timing affects costs: Spring (March-May): High demand, higher prices. Summer (June-August): Peak season, premium pricing. Autumn (September-November): Good conditions, moderate pricing. Winter (December-February): Lower demand, best prices but weather delays possible.
How to Keep Fencing Costs Down

Remove old fencing yourself if possible (save £5-15 per metre). Choose standard panel sizes rather than custom dimensions. Book work during quieter winter months for better rates. Get multiple quotes and compare specifications carefully. Consider sharing costs with neighbors for boundary fencing. Choose concrete posts for longer life and lower maintenance.

faqs.question: How much does fencing cost per metre in the UK?
faqs.answer: Fencing costs £30-80 per metre installed depending on type and height. Panel fencing costs £30-50 per metre, while closeboard fencing costs £40-65 per metre. Premium materials and complex sites cost more. Always get quotes including posts, gravel boards, and installation.

faqs.question: What's the difference between panel and closeboard fencing costs?
faqs.answer: Panel fencing costs £30-50 per metre and uses pre-made panels for quick installation. Closeboard fencing costs £40-65 per metre but offers better durability and wind resistance. Closeboard takes longer to install but provides a premium finish and can be fully customized.

faqs.question: Do I need planning permission for garden fencing?
faqs.answer: Most domestic fencing under 2 metres doesn't need planning permission. However, check for restrictions near highways (1m limit), in conservation areas, or for listed buildings. Always verify with your local planning authority and discuss boundary fencing with neighbors first.

faqs.question: How long does fence installation take?
faqs.answer: A typical garden fence (30-50 metres) takes 2-4 days depending on type and ground conditions. Panel fencing installs faster than closeboard. Hard ground, slopes, or access issues can extend timelines. Weather delays are common in winter months.

faqs.question: Should I use wooden or concrete fence posts?
faqs.answer: Concrete posts cost £5-10 more per metre but last 25-40 years versus 10-15 for wooden posts. They're worth the extra cost in wet or clay soils. Wooden posts are fine in well-drained soil and are easier to replace. Consider your soil conditions and budget.

faqs.question: Can I install fencing myself?
faqs.answer: DIY fencing can save 50-60% on labor costs but requires proper tools, time, and skill. You need post hole diggers, spirit level, and concrete mixing. Mistakes can be expensive to fix and may affect boundary relationships. Consider the time investment and physical effort required.

title: Handyman Costs UK 2026: Complete Price Guide for Odd Jobs and Repairs
excerpt: How much do handymen charge in 2026? Hourly rates, flat pack assembly, TV mounting, odd jobs, and repair prices across the UK.
author: TradeHub

content.text: Handymen tackle the small jobs that don't require specialist tradespeople, from flat pack assembly to minor repairs and odd jobs around the home. In 2026, expect to pay £25-45 per hour for handyman services, with many jobs priced as fixed rates rather than hourly charges. Here's your complete guide to handyman costs in the UK.
Average Handyman Hourly Rates

Handyman rates vary by location and skill level: General handymen charge £25-35 per hour across most of the UK. London and South East rates reach £35-50 per hour due to higher living costs. Multi-skilled handymen with specialist tools command £35-45 per hour. Many handymen charge a minimum of 2-3 hours even for small jobs, with call-out fees of £40-80 to cover travel time.
Day rates range from £200-300 for general handyman work, making them cost-effective for multiple small jobs or larger projects taking 6+ hours.
Common Handyman Jobs and Typical Costs

Flat pack furniture assembly: £40-120 per item depending on complexity (wardrobes cost more than chairs). TV mounting on wall: £60-120 including basic bracket. Picture hanging: £30-80 for multiple pictures. Install curtain poles: £40-100 depending on window size and pole type. Put up shelves: £50-150 for multiple shelves including brackets. Install door handles: £30-60 per door. Fix squeaky door: £25-50 including adjustment. Install smoke alarms: £40-80 per alarm including battery.
Property Maintenance and Repair Costs

Touch up paint work: £30-80 per room for minor touch-ups. Replace door locks: £60-150 including basic lock. Fill and paint small holes: £40-100 for multiple holes. Seal around bath/shower: £40-80 including materials. Fix loose tiles: £30-60 per tile depending on location. Replace tap washers: £40-80 including new washers. Adjust wardrobe doors: £30-60 for multiple doors.
Garden and Outdoor Handyman Jobs

Install garden shelving in shed: £60-150 depending on size and complexity. Put up outdoor washing line: £50-120 including posts if needed. Install garden gate hinges: £40-80 per gate. Repair garden furniture: £30-100 depending on extent. Clean and treat decking: £8-15 per square metre. Install outdoor lights: £80-200 depending on wiring requirements (may need electrician for complex wiring).
What Affects Handyman Costs?

Several factors influence pricing: Job complexity and time required (simple jobs are often fixed-price, complex repairs charged hourly), tools and materials needed (specialist tools may incur hire costs), travel distance (handymen typically serve local areas to minimize travel), minimum charges (most have 2-3 hour minimums), and timing (emergency or weekend work costs 25-50% more).
Flat Pack Assembly Specialists

Flat pack assembly pricing depends on item complexity: Simple items (chairs, small tables): £20-40 each. Medium items (bookcases, chest of drawers): £40-80 each. Complex items (wardrobes, bed frames): £80-150 each. Kitchen units: £15-30 per unit plus £100-200 setup fee. Many specialists offer fixed pricing based on product photos, providing certainty before booking.
TV Mounting and Technology Installation

Technology installation has become a major handyman service: TV wall mounting: £60-120 including basic bracket (customer supplies TV and bracket). Hide TV cables: Add £30-60 depending on cable length and wall type. Install surround sound: £100-250 depending on system complexity. Set up smart home devices: £40-100 per device for basic installation. Computer desk assembly: £60-150 depending on size and complexity.
When to Use a Handyman vs Specialist Tradesperson

Use handymen for: Non-structural repairs and adjustments, furniture assembly and installation, basic decorating and touch-ups, simple garden maintenance, minor plumbing (washers, basic leaks), basic electrical (changing fittings - but not wiring). Use specialist trades for: Structural work, gas appliances, complex electrical wiring, major plumbing, anything requiring building control approval.
How to Keep Handyman Costs Down

Bundle multiple small jobs into one visit to maximize the minimum charge period. Provide clear access and remove obstacles before the handyman arrives. Supply your own materials if the handyman agrees (though they may not warranty customer-supplied parts). Choose local handymen to minimize travel charges. Book during normal hours rather than evenings or weekends. Get fixed-price quotes for predictable jobs to avoid hour overruns.

faqs.question: How much do handymen charge per hour in the UK?
faqs.answer: Handymen charge £25-45 per hour depending on location and skills. General handymen average £25-35 per hour, while London rates reach £35-50 per hour. Most have minimum charges of 2-3 hours plus call-out fees of £40-80. Day rates of £200-300 are often more economical for multiple jobs.

faqs.question: What's the difference between a handyman and a specialist tradesperson?
faqs.answer: Handymen handle general repairs, assembly, and non-specialist work. They're typically less expensive but shouldn't do work requiring qualifications like gas work, major electrical, or structural changes. Specialist trades are essential for complex, safety-critical, or warranty-backed work.

faqs.question: How much does flat pack furniture assembly cost?
faqs.answer: Flat pack assembly costs £20-150 per item depending on complexity. Simple chairs cost £20-40, while complex wardrobes cost £80-150. Many specialists offer fixed pricing based on product photos. Factor in assembly time when comparing furniture prices - complex items can take 3-6 hours.

faqs.question: Should I supply materials or let the handyman provide them?
faqs.answer: Most handymen are happy either way. Supplying your own materials can save money but you take responsibility for compatibility and quantities. Handymen supplying materials is convenient and they take responsibility for suitability, though you'll pay a markup. Discuss both options when getting quotes.

faqs.question: Can handymen do electrical work?
faqs.answer: Handymen can change light fittings, install smoke alarms, and other simple tasks, but cannot install new circuits or do 'notifiable work' under Part P Building Regulations. For anything beyond basic replacement of existing fittings, use a qualified electrician to ensure safety and compliance.

faqs.question: How do I find a reliable handyman?
faqs.answer: Check local directories like TradeHub for reviewed handymen with verified customer feedback. Ask for references and photos of previous work. Start with a small job to test reliability and quality before booking larger projects. Ensure they have public liability insurance for your protection.
